ABSTRACT:

InjectingRunner allows a test-suite to be injectable. An arbitra=
ry number of implementations may inject into the suite, and the full suite =
is independently run for each implementation.

USE-CASE:

I recently wrote =
an interface that mimics a Table, a 2-dimensional array. I anticipated havi=
ng a couple implementations of this table, and wanted each to be compliant =
with the tests written for my interface.
Currently, I have to write tests f=
or each implementation. Instead, I wanted to be able to write one test-suit=
e that fully defines the interface, and simply say "Test using these Table =
implementations."
Furthermore, I imagine that if I ever distribute my inter=
face, third-parties may choose to implement their own Tables. They would ei=
ther have to write their own tests, or simply trust that they didn't make a=
ny mistakes. Instead, they can simply inject their implementations into my =
test suite, in the exact same way I'm doing now.

EXAMPLE:

As a quick exam=
ple, you could have the following test suite:

// ListTest.java (imports om=
itted for brevity)

// NoopRunner does nothing. This was the easiest way to=
 use familiar syntax while not having to explicitly omit this class every t=
ime I want to test.
@RunWith(NoopRunner.class)
public class ListTest {
  @I=
njected
  public List<String> list;

  @Test
  public testList() {
    list=
.add("A");
    assertThat(list.size(), is(1));
  }

}

// ArrayListTest.jav=
a (imports omitted for brevity)

@RunWith(InjectingRunner.class)
@InjectTes=
t(injectedValue=3DArrayList.class, testClass=3D ListTest.class)
public clas=
s ArrayListTest {
    // Do nothing; this is sufficient to create our test.=

}


// LinkedListTest.java (imports omitted for brevity)

@RunWith(Injecti=
ngRunner.class)
@InjectTest(injectedValue=3DLinkedList.class, testClass=3DL=
istTest.class)
public class LinkedListTest {
    // Do nothing; this is suf=
ficient to create our test.
}

And that's it. It's pretty experimental righ=
t now, and only does rudimentary validation, but it works, and generates se=
nsible output -- in Eclipse, ArrayListTest appears to own the methods actua=
lly in ListTest.

HOW TO USE:

It's very easy to retrofit an existing test =
suite to use this new injection runner; it boils down to removing the line =
in the @Before method and adding the annotations. Once that's complete, you=
r test framework can be generic to any subclass of that variable.

DETAILS:=


Internally, InjectingRunner is rather simple. It extends Runner and creat=
es a BlockJUnit4Runner for the referenced test-suite. That underlying class=
 handles finding the tests in the class, and running them.
Injection is don=
e by override withBefores, and just adding another Statement before any @Be=
fore's run. Since it's just using the standard stuff in the standard Runner=
, everything works as normal (You can use @Before, @BeforeClass, and everyt=
hing else you'd use in a normal test-suite).

FINAL THOUGHTS:

I was wonder=
ing if there was any interest in the source for this, or if I've foolishly =
reimplemented something already in JUnit. This has some similiarities to th=
e Theories runner, but that was too different to work well with this.
